thread.title: Ross Taylor brings up historic 17th ODI ton as Black Caps set SA 290 to win
thread.title_full: Ross Taylor brings up historic 17th ODI ton as Black Caps set SA 290 to win

author: Brendon Egan
title: Ross Taylor brings up historic 17th ODI ton as Black Caps set SA 290 to win
text:
Ross Taylor brings up historic 17th ODI ton as Black Caps set SA 290 to win BRENDON EGAN Last updated 14:56, February 22 2017 Iain McGregor/ Fairfax NZ 
Kane Williamson drives against South Africa at Hagley Oval during his knock of 69. 
Ross Taylor hit a record-breaking 17th one-day century off the final ball as New Zealand set South Africa 290 to win the second one-day international in Christchurch. 
Taylor brought the sold out 8000 crowd at Hagley Oval to their feet on Wednesday, whacking Wayne Parnell for a boundary off the last delivery of the innings to finish 102 not out. 
The veteran Black Caps' batsman owns the record by himself after he was previously stuck on 16 ODI centuries with Nathan Astle. JOHN DAVIDSON/PHOTOSPORT 
Tom Latham's poor run with the bat in one-day internationals continued in Christchurch. 
Taylor and James Neesham, who impressed with 71 from 57 balls, achieved an unbeaten fifth wicket stand of 123 runs, to get New Zealand through to 289-4. 
READ MORE: 
New Zealand finished slightly short of where they would have wanted to be, given they were 155-2 after 30 overs with Taylor and Kane Williamson looking strong at the crease. JOHN DAVIDSON/PHOTOSPORT 
South Africa celebrate the wicket of Tom Latham in the second ODI in Christchurch. 
Taylor hit eight fours in his 110-ball innings. He was almost caught by David Miller on the boundary off the penultimate ball, but he chucked the ball back as he clashed with the boundary rope. 
Right-armer Dwaine Pretorius in just his sixth ODI for South Africa, was impressive taking 2-40 from his 10 overs. 
New Zealand were in danger of falling away once Williamson and Neil Broom were removed within the space of 13 balls, leaving them 166-4 in the 33rd over. 
Williamson and Taylor consolidated after opener Dean Brownlie went for 32, putting on 104 for the third wicket. 
In typical fashion, the pair didn't take many risks. They were prepared to work the ball into the gaps and get accustomed to a slower Hagley Oval wicket early on. 
Williamson brought up his 29th ODI half century, reaching his 50 from 59 balls. 
The partnership was looking threatening with New Zealand targeting a score well over 300, until legspinner Imran Tahir achieved the key wicket. 
Tahir tossed the ball up to Williamson, who mistimed his shot straight to Andile Phehlukwayo at long on, ending their century-run stand. 
At 155-2 after 30 overs and Williamson and Taylor at the crease, New Zealand were nicely placed. 
Williamson went at a crucial time for 69 after New Zealand's best two batsmen had frustrated the South African attack for 18 overs. 
Taylor celebrated his 50 shortly after, becoming the quickest New Zealand ODI batsman to post 6000 runs in 166 innings. 
South Africa pulled off a double breakthrough with Broom picking out JP Duminy at point and removed for just two. 
Opener Tom Latham again fell cheaply for two, chipping one to Phehlukwayo at square leg from Wayne Parnell's bowling. 
It was the fifth straight single digit score in an ODI from the Cantabrian, who has scored just 35 runs from six innings since his career-best 137 against Bangladesh at Hagley on Boxing Day. 
With Martin Guptill set to return from a hamstring injury for game four in Hamilton and Brownlie's solid displays with the bat in his three ODIs since rejoining the Black Caps, Latham will be a nervous man. 
He may get one last chance to impress in Saturday's third ODI in Wellington. 
Brownlie was beginning to look comfortable after a cautious start, but was trapped in front by Pretorius. 
Replays suggested the ball was missing and heading down leg, but Williamson at the other end declined to review. 
Brownlie and Williamson had taken the score through to 53 after Latham's early departure. 
The 32-year-old right hander had taken three boundaries of a Chris Morris over and was starting to look like he was on track to notch his second ODI half century. 
Skipper AB de Villiers sent a brief scare through the South African camp.He received medical attention to his right shoulder in the sixth over after landing awkwardly while trying to effect a run out at the non-strikers end. 
The brilliant South African batsman shook off the discomfort to remain on the field. 
New Zealand named an unchanged line-up, sticking with legspinner Ish Sodhi, rather than bringing in an extra pace bowler in Lockie Ferguson or Matt Henry. 
The Proteas made three changes with hard-hitting left-hander Miller recovering from a finger injury to feature for the first time on the New Zealand tour. 
Star pace bowler Kagiso Rabada was scratched due to a knee niggle, while Farhaan Behardien and chinaman bowler Tabraiz Shamsi dropped out of the playing 11 from Hamilton. 
The world's No1 ranked ODI team brought in pace bowlers Parnell and Pretorius. 
South Africa are on a 12-game ODI winning run. Their last loss came on June 24 last year against the West Indies in Bridgetown. 
If they can beat the Black Caps in Christchurch, they would achieve the South African ODI record and move to second outright on the all-time list behind the Australian team of 2003. - Stuff
